did.unittitle: St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Detroit, Mich., Records 1885-1998
did.abstract: Church established as mission Sunday School in 1884 and disbanded in 1988 because of declining membership. Registers of baptisms, marriages, burials and communicants; registers of church services; vestry minutes, annual parish meeting minutes, bishop's committee minutes, correspondence, budgets and treasurer's annual reports, and photograph albums.

acqinfo.p: The record group was part of a larger accession (Donor No. 1059) received from the Episcopal Church, Diocese of Michigan in June 1993 and March 2002.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Detroit, Mich., Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: St. Thomas began as a mission Sunday School in Detroit, Michigan in 1883. In 1884 the Sunday School was transferred to a chapel at the corner of Shady Lane and West Grand Boulevard. In 1900 St. Thomas became a parish. New buildings were added and the parish thrived until the 1930s. After a long period of financial difficulties, St. Thomas reverted to mission status in 1963. In 1988 the church was forced to close due to declining membership. A complete history of St. Thomas is found in the folder titled "Background Materials."

scopecontent.p: The records of St. Thomas Episcopal Church document the history of an urban Detroit church and span the years 1885 to 1988. The record groups has been arranged into the following series: registers of baptisms, burials, marriages, communicants; registers of church services; vestry minute books; office files, and photograph albums.

scopecontent.p: The most important administrative records are the two volumes of vestry minutes dating from 1917 to 1923 and 1954 to 1968. Each of the volumes contains, in addition to minutes of the vestry, minutes of the bishop's committee records and of the annual parish meeting. The volume for the years 1954 to 1968 includes discussions the flight of many parishioners to the suburbs, the integration of minorities into the life of the parish, and specifics of the reversion of the church to mission status.

scopecontent.p: The office files include a miscellanea of scattered minutes and administrative papers. Of particular interest is the folder of material for Allen Grey. Mr. Grey held an office in St. Thomas from 1947 to 1982 and for most of that time served as senior warden. His correspondence contains both letters received and carbon copies of letters sent. The latter reveal, in colorful language, the thoughts and activities of a man passionately committed to his church and deeply concerned with the welfare of his fellow parishioners. This series also contains an Inventory of Furnishings and Memorials, created in 1966 by Winifred Gerow, who is identified in the photograph album as the historian of St. Thomas. The inventory was originally kept in a three ring binder. It is arranged chronologically by the object's date of acquisition or donation. Each page contains a description of an item and often includes interesting footnotes pertaining to its use or influence on parishioners or giving personal information about the donors.
